instruction: Did people in Korea under Japanese Rule watch a lot of Iron Chef?
reference: No. The first televisions were sold in 1946. Iron Chef started airing in 1993.

instruction: Why do some English languages add an 'R' to words that end with an 'A'?
reference:
You'll normally only hear this in non-rhotic (non-'R'-pronouncing) accents when one word ends with a vowel sound, and the next one *starts* with a vowel sound.

Non-rohtic accents have what's called a [Linking R](_URL_0_), where words that end with an R won't have the R pronounced when the word is said in isolation, but *will* have the R pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel sound.

The phenomenon you're seeing is an over-extension of the above rule, called an [Intrusive R](_URL_1_), where the rule for linking Rs is over applied, and pronounced between *any* two words where the first ends in a (specific kind of) vowel sound, and the second begins with a vowel sound.

instruction: Do quadragenarian's have little memory capacity?
reference: No. Quadragenarians are people that are in their 40s. As people age, their memory can get worse. Half of people over age 50 have mild to severe memory loss. Ken Jennings was 46 years old when he won Jeopardy! The Greatest of All Time tournament.

instruction: Why TV antennas improves reception when held in hand?
reference:
Ok so First off, its a law of conductivity. Your body is a natural conductor, and can conduct electricity. Your body absorbs and can pass on electrical currents and direct them into the antenna.

Trust me on this, I work for the telephone company and we use this as a way to trace phone lines all the time. Its called induction.

Your body, when you touch the antenna, becomes part of the antenna and can do 1 of 2 things. 1, it can help by removing and grounding out certain unneeded signals temporarily. By providing a path to ground, the EM frequencies are being grounded out and thereby eliminating interference by allowing the signals that you are trying to see, to be stronger than the ones you are trying to ignore. The 2nd thing, is that when you touch the antenna, your body extends the antennas surface area by a degree, and instead of the thin metal wires being the only conductors, it now uses you to catch and route signal to the antenna.

In essence, either way, when you touch it you become part of the conductor itself.

instruction: Could Godzilla have been killed by the Tohoku earthquake?
reference: No. The Tohoku earthquake led to the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant meltdown. Nuclear meltdowns lead to a release of deadly levels of radiation. Godzilla draws power from radiation and is not hurt by it.

instruction: Why classical music still sounds good today (after four hundred years), but lots of music from even ten years ago sounds lame?
reference: When you hear classical music, you basically only hear the classical music that was good.  In the era of digitally recorded media, pretty much anyone with a microphone can record anything, and store it and transmit it anywhere for free, so it's easy to find the full range of music, from awesome to awful.

instruction: Sometimes, in my sleep, I have "memories" of the future, prior to them happening, and I don't remember it until it happens. Why/how does this happen?
reference:
This doesn't happen. That you *think* it happens is due to your brain (and everyone elses) being susceptible to a wide range of [cognitive biases](_URL_0_).

It's difficult to simply state a single reason, but in this case there's certainly a very plausible explanation. Your 'predictions' are extremely vague events, likely not very well remembered in the first place. A wide range of real life situations could fit them. Plus, you'll tend not to remember ones that don't 'come true', but when they do you may feel you remember them very clearly and even embellish them with new information in hindsight - you wouldn't know you're doing it, it's just something your brain does. People are well documented displaying a range of amazing misperceptions of this type, such as describing entire false memories without realising.

If you honestly feel you have magical powers, nobody will give you any scientific credit unless you can prove it. That would involve making well documented predictions before events take place, then well documenting the actual events and verifying their similarities in a statistically improbable way. This would all need to be done under double blind conditions and so on, to really do it properly.

instruction: why does my hair go darker when it's wet, when water is clear?
reference:
I'm no scientist, but this is eli5 and there is no response yet, so i'll wing it: water attenuates light. That is, the layer of water on your head doesn't reflect as much light as it would normally (dry), because not as much reflected light reaches your eye as it would when it's dry.

Edit: It got me thinking, so i had to verify my own suspicion... I measured the reflectance of my own wet hair relative to it being dry. It's a little noisy as i spent maybe 30 seconds setting it up, and it's far from ideal, but I think this cooroborates what i postulate. ()[_URL_0_]

instruction: Why don't the gas pumps have a cash option?
reference:
I used to manage a gas station, so hopefully I can answer a few of your questions. 

First off, cash acceptors in gas pumps exist. If I'm  not mistaken, both Dresser Wayne and Gilbarco (two of the big manufacturers) make them, and have made them for a while. They have several notable drawbacks.

Automatic Cash Acceptors, ACAs, are both unreliable and inaccurate. Everyone has dealt with them in things like soda machines. They take bills without giving credit, give back incorrect change, and jam up regularly. All of these issues add overhead costs for the gas station and royally piss off customers.

ACA's require frequent cash refills and empties. ATM's are refilled by armed guards, which are very expensive and are usually billed by the minute for their time, armored truck time, and driver time. A gas station full of ACAs would require daily service from a security company, which again adds overhead costs for the gas station.

ACA's are big targets for theft. A lone ATM is already a pretty high risk, and has many security features built in to deter theft. If you put 8-10 ACA's in a single gas station lot, you run a much higher risk of theft.

ACA's by their very nature lose the gas station money. Gas stations make almost all their profits from customers coming into the store and buying drinks and whatnot. Customers paying cash at the pump reduces that profit.

So an ACA upsets customers, costs a lot of money, and creates a higher risk of theft and property damage. It's a lose:lose:lose kind of situation in most cases.

instruction: How are drug sniffing dogs trained to recognize the smell of drugs?
reference:
The dogs are trained with a small quantity of the real drug. A toy is hidden and they are rewarded when they find it. Then the toy is stuffed with a bag of a drug, shown to the dog so it knows the smell, and the dog rewarded when it can find it. Then the bag is hidden without the toy and the dog rewarded upon finding it.

As for ignoring food, the dogs are trained to be in "work mode" for the search. If they are going crazy alerting on the treat bag or goofing off then they don't get rewarded and are scolded. They even might hide some treats around the same area as the bag, and only let them actually get the treat as a reward if they find the bag, but not the hidden treats.

Dogs are smart enough to figure out that they only get the reward if they find the bag.

instruction: Would a cattle farmer be useful to a drum maker?
reference: Yes. Cattle are often slaughtered for meat and other products, like leather. Drums are often made with leather.

instruction: The controversy over Sandra bland possibly being deceased in her mugshot photo and the evidence supporting either side of the argument.
reference: Um. There is controversy... because if Sandra Bland was dead in her mugshot photo that would be really fucked up and would make the police look bad. Is that something you think wouldn't be controversial?

instruction: Can a grey seal swim in the same water as the subject of Moby Dick?
reference: Yes. The range of gray seals is limited to parts of the northern hemisphere bordered by the Atlantic ocean. The subject of Moby Dick was a sperm whale. Sperm whales can be found in the north Atlantic, in addition to most other bodies of water on earth.

instruction: How do sexual fetishisms start?
reference:
There are many theories, but I am a diaper fetishist (which is fairly uncommon), and I have spent the better part of my life trying to figure out where in the hell it comes from. 

My parents divorced when I was about five or six, and I remember just waking up one day and my mother was gone. No goodbye, no preparation, just gone, and so I sort of felt like she was "torn" from me. I think something in me wanted to return to a time when she was still with us and somehow my five year old brain latched on to diapers as that connection. I was wearing diapers when she still lived with us, so my brain associated diapers with stability, love, and my mother. Many psychologists believe those formative years are incredibly important and the "mental map" that you develop in those years is the same map you will use the rest of my life. I never really got to experience that whole nurturing period of my life when I was little, and I guess I never really got over it. My dad was a loving man, but very strict, and would yell, scream, and throw me across the room for such small infractions as not taking out the trash. So I guess a desire to wear diapers is what helped me mentally escape such a rough upbringing and put myself in a place where I was comforted, loved, and cared for.

For the most part I've been able to keep my diaper wearing discreet, as I am at least cognizant enough of the fact that what I enjoy isn't normal so I don't expose unwilling parties to it. A couple close friends know, and also my wife knows and indulges me from time to time, and for the most part it is a private affair. I am very successful, have a career, a beautiful wife, make lots of money, and am generally happy with how my life is going, so I am at least fortunate in that it doesn't have any tangible negative effect on my life. I wear them maybe once a week or so, sometimes twice a week. However, if I could change one thing in my life, I would definitely wish I didn't have a diaper fetish, but I am a realist and I know that is just not going to happen. I am now 30 and I don't remember a time in my life in which I didn't want to wear diapers, and I've come to accept there probably won't be a time I don't want to either. I've struggled with it my whole life, but I realize now that it is part of my "core" of who I am, and having this fetish has made me more accepting of people who do things I don't agree with, less judgmental of other people, and more sensitive to other people's wants and desires. So I guess you could say trying to remove it would remove a core aspect of who I am and would likely change the type of person I have become. Since I'm happy with who I am, I'll just accept it. Telling me to "just quit" is as impossible as telling me to not like baseball, or to stop liking video games. Sure you can TELL yourself you don't like those things any more, but you can't really lie to yourself that well and you know how you really feel. So that's how my fetish started.

TL;DR Had a diaper fetish since my earliest memories, came from my mother leaving me at a young age and strict upbringing by my father.

edit: To clarify to those who have never heard of people like me, this has absolutely NOTHING to do with children. Child pornography is a disgusting, despicable practice and the grand majority of people who share my interests feel the same way. 

edit 2: I should do an AMA...this is fun! I'd love to dispel some misconceptions about people like me.

instruction: Would Jacques Duèze have been friends with Richard Dawkins?
reference: No. Jacques Duèze was later Pope John XXII. The Pope is the head of the Catholic Church, a Christian organization. Christianity is a religion. Richard Dawkins is a prominent critic of religion.

instruction: Why those ads for mobile games aren't illegal
reference:
The copyright holder (The company that makes or distributes The Witcher) would need to make a claim to the picture/icon.

It is technically illegal.  It sounds like this game/company is committing copyright infringement.

instruction: What is the purpose of this wall outlet?
reference:
Is it a connector for cable television service?

Cable television wall plates are typically a single "F" type RF connector on a plate by themself, or sometimes on the same plate with a phone jack.


(/Short comment)

instruction: Did occupants of Vellore Fort need to defend themselves from Grizzly Bears?
reference: No. The Vellore Fort was a 16th century stronghold in India. Grizzly Bears are native to the North American continent.

instruction: Can Family of Barack Obama ride comfortably in 2020 Jaguar F Type?
reference: No. Barack Obama has a wife and two children. The 2020 Jaguar F Type is a car that seats two people.

instruction: Could a white cockatoo have lived through the entire Thirty Years' War?
reference: Yes. The Thirty Years' War lasted 30 years. White cockatoos have been reported to live between 40-60 years in captivity.

instruction: What would be different In America if it had no debt?
reference:
No debt at all?  We'd have a radically different economic system.

The US *must* carry some debt for our current system to function.  Investors rely on access to government debt (bonds) to act as a relative safe haven for a portion of their investment balance.

If America's budget was magically balanced with mystery funds every year you'd see higher government expenditure on social programs, infrastructure, and the military.

instruction: Did King of Portuguese people in 1515 have familial ties to the Tudors?
reference: Yes. Manuel I was King of Portugal from 1495 to 1521. Manuel I of Portugal married Maria of Aragon. Maria of Aragon was the sister of Catherine of Aragon. Catherine of Aragon was the first wife of Henry VIII and was one of a handful that he did not behead.

instruction: Why isn't the decimeter used very much in metric measurement?
reference:
people dont usually use the middle measurements because they are a bit redundant. while you could change units every magnitude of 10, people usually only do it for magnitudes of 1000. the most common metric measurements are kilo, regular, mili, micro, and nano. all of those are 3 decimal spaces apart. deci, hecto, deca and the ones inbetween are not used because its easier to say 10m. once the numbers go to thousands of meters, its usually changed to kilometers. 

centimeter is sorta a special case. i guess its used more often then the others because its the most convinient measurement for our human scale world. most objects can be measured in cm without it being too big or too small of a measurement

instruction: How come humans must cook their meat but animals can eat raw carcasses?
reference:
We don't have to cook our meat. 

Sushi.

Tartar.

Cooking meat makes more of it digestible and kills pathogens. We are relatively pathogen and parasite free compared to most wild animals.

instruction: Why are some people very easily motivated to workout and can self motivate while others have severe difficulty self motivating or continuing good habits?
reference:
I think the nature vs nurture part of the debate is one we probably won't have an answer to for quite some time. Though regardless of its origin, I would say it's definitely a psychological thing.

I would suspect part of the differences would be due each person's level of intrinsic (internal) motivation to go to the gym. If someone is intrinsically motivated to go to the gym, it means they personally enjoy the task, enjoy the benefits, and are driven to go to the gym from a place within themselves, not relying on being motivated by outside sources. There are different types and strengths of intrinsic motivation that could fit along a spectrum, ranging from something like *"I'm motivated because I SHOULD go to the gym and I know it's healthy for me"* being on the weaker end of things, to *"I'm motivated to go to the gym because I enjoy the process, I love the way it makes me feel, I genuinely care for me health and want to keep myself healthy, and love everything about the activity (e.g., dieting, the biological aspect of it, etc)"*. So depending on where you end up along that spectrum will ultimately affect your motivation to go.

I think this then begs the question, what is ultimately driving your internal motivation to do these things? The driving force here may be to stay healthy and to improve the way you look physically. Going to the gym is a way you can meet these internal goals you have set for yourself. At the same time, you might not enjoy the exercises the gym has to offer, and going to the gym might just not be the right type of exercise for you. In this case, you care about your health and the way you look and you are intrinsically motivated by these things, but the barrier to you reaching these goals would actually be the activity you're choosing to do to meet them. 

I think in your own circumstance (while trying to not turn this into an advice thread), picking up on you saying *"even if they know it is good for them and brings good results"* makes me think you choose to go to the gym because you think you *should* go. You know it's good for you, but it is not necessarily something you are intrinsically motivated to do on your own accord. The language difference here, compared to a person that says "I go to the gym because I *want* to go", I think shows a difference in where your motivation may lie.

And often for people and their health it's all about finding the right motivation, and the right activity to do that enables them to meet their own goals. So using myself as an example: I personally am a rock climber. While it is an activity I do so that I keep healthy physically ad mentally, it is an activity I also enjoy for a number of reasons other than purely the health benefits it brings me. So I don't just go because I'm going to get fitter, I go because I absolutely love everything else there is about the sport. The enjoyment of the movement, the physical and mental challenge it brings, and an enjoyment of managing and using the equipment involved is what motivates me. I'm motivated to become a better climber and reach new goals in terms of how hard I can climb. I love the outdoors, which is where rock climbing takes me. What I'm *not* motivated by is to have an overly muscular physique or to get big, as I find it kinda useless other than looking good in a way society says I should, which I don't subscribe to. So rock climbing meets these goals pretty well. I also do yoga occasionally, as I know it's great for me and keeps my mind and body happy, which I feel that I do care about deeply. I love the way I feel during and after yoga, and I can see the benefits it brings to other areas of my life. However, I experience a number of other barriers to doing yoga, such as cost and time commitment, and it comes second to rock climbing which I put all my extra time and energy into.

So yeah, that's more than I was planning to write about myself. Hopefully you can see the point I was trying to make.

Edit: Where I have motivational issues is with getting my uni work done, which is probably what leads me to writing long replies on motivation in /r/eli5 -_-

instruction: Was Augustus his real name?
reference: No. Augustus was given the name Gaius Octavius at birth. After he was adopted by his uncle Julius Caesar, he took the name Gaius Iulius Caesar. He took the name Augustus upon the breaking of the ruling Triumvirate and becoming Emperor.

instruction: Did the 40th president of the United States forward lolcats to his friends?
reference: No. The 40th president of the United States was Ronald Reagan. Ronald Reagan died in 2004. The first recorded use of the term lolcat occurred in 2006.

instruction: Is J.D. Salinger's most successful work influential to killers?
reference: Yes. J.D. Salinger's most popular work was Catcher in the Rye. John Hinckley Jr. tried to assassinate Ronald Reagan after reading Catcher in the Rye. Mark David Chapman had a copy of Catcher in the Rye when he assassinated John Lennon. Robert John Bardo carried a copy of Catcher in the Rye when he murdered actress Rebecca Schaeffer.

instruction: Does Post Malone have a fear of needles?
reference: No. Post Malone's body is covered with many tattoos. The most common method of tattooing in modern times is the electric tattoo machine, which inserts ink into the skin via a single needle or a group of needles that are soldered onto a bar, which is attached to an oscillating unit.

instruction: Have Jamie Lee Curtis been the subject of fake news?
reference: Yes. Fake news is a hoax that is circulated and spreads to get people to believe a falsehood. Jamie Lee Curtis is an American actress known for the Halloween series. Rumors have been spread about Jamie Lee Curtis that she was born a hermaphrodite.

instruction: Can Simon Cowell vote for the next Supreme Court judge?
reference: No. The Supreme Court is the highest court in the USA. Simon Cowell is a British talent competition judge. Members of the Supreme Court are appointed, rather than elected.

instruction: How did early highway builders know if they were building their roads in the right direction/angle?
reference:
You ever see those guys along the side of the road with a tripod and a bunch of flags and stakes?

They're surveyors. It's their job to make sure things like roads are *exactly* where they are supposed to be. They take sightings, and then do the math. A little trigonometry and a good [theodolite](_URL_0_) can get you an incredibly exact measurement.

instruction: Did Helen Keller ever read a novel by J. K. Rowling?
reference: No. Helen Keller died in 1968. J. K. Rowling's first novel was published in 1997.

instruction: why concept cars look so good but never turn out that way?
reference: Concept cars are the same thing as the weird ass wacky coat you see at a Paris fashion show. "Who the hell would wear that thing?" Well, no one- but it does give a lot of good inspiration to other designers to craft interesting clothing that will be available to the mainstream consumer. The same is true for concept cars: you don't see some wild 2070s looking dart car cruising down the highway, but you do see a new Honda Prius with paneling and curves, or interior features influenced by that concept.

instruction: Do guitarist's have fingers that can handle pain better than average?
reference: Yes. Guitarists typically have calloused fingertips.  Callouses are formed of layers of dead skin and usually lack sensation.

instruction: What makes an organic molecule "organic?" How is it fundamentally different from a regular/inert molecule?
reference: When it comes to chemistry, organic means carbon.  Molecules with a carbon atom in it are considered organic.

instruction: Why is "Pulp Fiction" so universally praised?
reference: [This previous post](_URL_0_) on why Tarantino is popular sums it up pretty well.

instruction: Did Queen Elizabeth I read the works of Jean-Paul Sartre?
reference: No. Jean-Paul Sartre was born in 1905. Queen Elizabeth I died in 1603.

instruction: What is going on with all the tension in the world?
reference:
I think that the information age is hitting full stride and we are all seeing only the worst from every country or spot in the world... 

It's like with anything on a small scale, take for example incidents with police in America, we only see the worst sides of it we never see the good and if we do see the good it's only for a flash and then it's back to something terrible.

The old saying is if it bleeds it leads and in the last 20 years we've opened up a lot of sources of information and in all of them, if it bleeds it leads so that's bound to just, cause tension.

instruction: why are people protesting the G20 summit in Germany? Isn't the worlds leaders coming together to discuss economy a good thing?
reference:
There are a lot of groups that show up to these things.

Some are nationalists upset that their leaders are wasting time on the interests of other nations.

Some are globalists upset that the G20 isn't including other nations.

Some are activists trying to get publicity for their cause and aren't all that upset about the G20 summit.

Some are Anarchists who show up to every large protest to cause trouble.

Some are supporters counter-protesting.

instruction: Why do so many bands play their song with a faster beat when they play live than they do on the recorded version?
reference: I can explain my personal experience with this.  Energy!  When my old bands and I used to record, our drummers were timing with a metronome to keep a steady beat with each track.  When we used to play live we would occasionally play faster.  Most of us would not notice it, but people would mention it to us later.  The drummer would get excited and start playing harder and faster.

instruction: Why does looking directly at the sun hurt your eyes, but looking a few degrees away from the sun does not?
reference:
The sun is a giant nuclear reactor in space blasting radiation in all directions, and it puts out so much radiation that it actually heats the earth. So if you just stare right at it, the radiation is going straight to the back of your eyes and burning the inside back part of your eyes. 

If you aren't looking right at it, those radiation waves are hitting the outside protective part of your eye (or at least not the very back where your critical receptors are).

instruction: Were number of states in Ancient Greece underwhelming compared to US states in 1900?
reference: No. In the year 1900 there were 42 US states. Ancient Greece had several hundred relatively independent city-states called poleis.

instruction: Did Brazilian jiu-jitsu Gracie founders have at least a baker's dozen of kids between them?
reference: Yes. A baker's dozen refers to 13 of anything. Brazilian jiu-jitsu was founded by Carlos and Helio Gracie.   Helio Gracie had 9 children. Carlos Gracie had 11 children.

instruction: How Bob Saget got his reputation as being a perverted old maniac? I only know him from Full House where he seemed quite wholesome. What did he do on or off the screen to gain this rep?
reference:
* In the 80s, Saget was a stand up comic, and his act was fairly adult.
* As part of the comedy boom of the 80's, TV shows were looking for comics, and lot of them made a quick buck making crappy pilots that never saw the light of day.
* Saget's crappy pilot *did* see the light of day, and he went from being an adult comic to a wholesome family entertainer, because the money was good.
* His apparently wholesome image led to another inane TV show, *America's Funniest Home Videos*, again because the money was good.
* Now that those shows have run their course Saget is being *extra* dirty, to distance himself from them.

instruction: Is it common for women to have moustaches?
reference: No. Facial hair doesn't normally grow on women like it does on men. A little bit of hair can grow between the upper lip and nose but it's a very small amount and generally not enough to be noticeable.

instruction: Did Christopher Columbus go to Antarctica?
reference: No. Between 1492 and 1503, Columbus completed four round-trip voyages between Spain and the Americas.  His expeditions, sponsored by the Catholic Monarchs of Spain, were the first European contact with the Caribbean, Central America, and South America. Antarctica is Earth's southernmost continent.

instruction: why is Puerto Rico broke?
reference: The big, ELI5 picture? They are compelled to abide by certain U.S. policy (like medicare/medicaid), but because they aren't a state don't get federal fund to cover. For a time, congress set up tax benefits for businesses to locate in PR and that helped boost jobs, taxes and pay for these programs. Then Congress repealed the laws, the companies left, so more people needed government assistance and at the same time the tax revenues to cover these programs were drastically cut.

instruction: Can Poland Spring make money in the Sahara?
reference: Yes. The Sahara is the largest hot desert. Deserts are dry regions that receive little precipitation. Poland Spring sells bottled water.

instruction: Is basil safe from Hypervitaminosis D?
reference: Yes. Hypervitaminosis D is a rare disease caused by having too much vitamin D. Basil contains many vitamins including Vitamin A, B, C, E, and K.
